    Getting started with the SWARM Simulation Platform

    These brief instructions will help you get started with the simulator. The other topics in this help provide additional information and detail about working with other aspects of this platform.

    Building a Simulation

    Follow these instructions to build your first simulation.

    1. Access the Main Site

    First, access the main site at SWARM. If you haven’t already, sign up for an account and make sure that you are signed in. You should be seeing the main Forum page.

    2. Navigate to the dashboard

    Navigate to the Simulation Dashbaord by using the top navigation bar menu Simulation or by clicking the blue button that says Simulator on the left hand side of the screen.

    3. Choose a Scenario

    Once on the Simulation dashboard, click the green button at the top that says Create A Simulation. This will take you to the index for the simulations that are provided. For this tutorial, we will be using the Rendezvous scenario but any scenario can be completed with these steps.

    4. Set the Runtime

    Each simulation can run for up to 5 minutes, with this time cap being extended with a Premium account. Slide the ruler to select the amount of time to alot. In general, you will want to give yourself a bit of extra time to ensure that any and all real-world effects are mitigated.

    Once completed, click the green button on the bottom that says Next.

    5. Set up your SWARM

    Next, you will build your swarm. For the purpose of this scenario, you must have at least 2 agents. Slide the ruler to select up to 8 agents.

    Next, choose the features that you wish to add. You can select to add a Perception system and an Obstacle Avoidance system. Briefly, the perception system allows you to detect objects in your environment while the obstacle avoidance system provides very basic avoidance of the ground, trees, rocks and other surface objects. See the note below on more information.

    Once completed, select the green button that says Create Swarm. You will be notified if successful and then taken to the next page.

    • Note: This is meant as a brief overview. For more information about the individual agents, please see [SWARM Infrastructure][mydoc_infrastructure].

    6. Set the parameters of your algorithm

    Next, you need to set the parameters of your algorithm.

    • Amount of Time Between Time Steps - This parameter describes how much time should elapse between the running of your algorithm. This loosely translates to the number of hertz that your algorithm runs. For example, if the time is set of 0.5 seconds, then the algorithm you choose will run twice in one second.
    • Max Communication Distance - Currently, this feature provides a maximum distance between agents that any two agents can communicate. If two agents are beyond this distance, any messages sent to that agent will not be received.

    Once selected, click Submit to move on to the next page.

    7. Input your algorithm

    This section is the most technical of the platform. Step 4 represents the intelligence of the swarm and allows you to be able to write and design complex algorithms.

    A common question at this stage is “Does each agent run a version of this code?”. The answer is yes, each agent is given a copy of this code and runs this code at every timestep completely independently of the other agents. A key feature of this platform is the fact that each agent is completely independent and can operate without any input from any other agent.

    To start, you will need to define a set of states that your swarm will be in. States act as independent modules that your agents run indivdually. As can be seen, two states initialize and rendezvous have been created. You can modify these if you wish but for the purpose this tutorial, we will not.

    Next, you must validate each state that you have created. As can be seen in the code, each state is defined as a Python function. This function must return 3 items: next_position as a list, message as a dict and next_state as a string. You can also return a boolean False value. Either are accepted. Code validation will ensure that you have no syntax errors and that your function executed. IT IS NOT checking if your code is “correct” or will complete the objective.

    Validate the initialize funciton, which is required, first. Then, validate the rest of your states. Once validated, click the button at the bottom of the page called “Finalize and Submit”.

    8. Name & Submit

    Add a name and then choose to either submit your simulation to be run or save to run at a later date.

    Once submitted, you will receive emails and notifiations about the status. Once you see that the simulation has been completed, you will be able to view the data analysis section. See [Data Analysis][mydoc_data_analysis] for more information.
